thread.title: Missing Marmite and bye bye Ben & Jerry's: Is Brexit hitting our supermarket shelves?
thread.title_full: Missing Marmite and bye bye Ben & Jerry's: Is Brexit hitting our supermarket shelves?

author: Chris Knight
title: Missing Marmite and bye bye Ben & Jerry's: Is Brexit hitting our supermarket shelves?
text:
Missing Marmite and bye bye Ben & Jerry's: Is Brexit hitting our supermarket shelves? 10:57, 13 Oct 2016 10:58, 13 Oct 2016 By Chris Knight The alleged row has hit online shelves, with the likes of Marmite, PG Tips, and Ben and Jerry's all being pulled Share Get what's on news by email An alleged row has broken out between Tesco and Unilever 
Brexit has been blamed for many things, but it now faces the charge of costing us Marmite and other household brands. 
An alleged row has broken out between Tesco and one of its largest suppliers Unilever as a result of the weakening pound. 
In response to the dispute, the supermarket giant is understood to have pulled thousands of Unilever products from their online shelves. 
Marmite, Hellmann’s, Domestos, Flora, and Surf are brands among many others to have been caught in the firing line. 
But why are Tesco and Unilever rumoured to be locking horns? 
Here’s a quick explainer of the row: So, what is actually happening? 
Tesco has pulled thousands of products from their online store in an alleged row with one of their leading suppliers. 
As well as the brands mentioned above, the likes of PG Tips, Pot Noodle, Cornetto, Walls, Cif, and Ben & Jerry’s are also all currently unavailable for internet shoppers. Is it really because of Brexit? 
Strangely enough, it actually is. 
Unilever is believed to have stopped their deliveries to Tesco, after the supermarket giants refused to agree to their plans to raise prices by 10% due to the falling value of the pound against the euro and dollar. 
Since Britain voted to leave the EU, the value of the pound has dropped by an average of 17%. So does this mean no more Marmite? 
For the half of you who love Marmite, the good news is you’re still able to buy the stuff. 
Tesco shoppers will still be able to pick up Unilever products in stores, although stock levels are said to be running low. 
Rival supermarkets such as Asda and Sainsburys all currently appear to be stocking the items as normal. What has Tesco said? 
A Tesco spokesperson said: “We are currently experiencing availability issues on a number of Unilever products. We hope to have this issue resolved soon.” What has Unilever said?
